3390/A0/04/016/002.indicator_name: Number of monitoring reports on child-related public policies developed by surveillance spaces at national level and in prioritized regions
3390/A0/04/016/002.headline: By providing technical assistance to government and supporting efforts to monitor child-focused public spending  UNICEF has helped put investment in children on the public agenda. For example  the National Action Plan for Children and Adolescents has become law and child-focused public spending has been included in the budget law.

3390/A0/04/015/003.status_value: Level 3: The National Yachay Programme has a guide for educators that has been validated in Andean and Amazonian contexts and includes content and sessions on building social skills in adolescents through sport for development.  Level 4: 34 educators from 5 regions have been trained in the methodology. Improved sport for development implementation guide.
3390/A0/04/015/003.indicator_name: Number of institutions that have a methodology of improvement of social skills  incorporating the approach of gender  for adolescents of the most excluded groups.
3390/A0/04/015/003.headline: The national Yachay programme has a guide for educators on improving social skills through sport and has allocated budgetary resources for prevention strategies based in this methodology. Also  two local governments in Andean regions are implementing strategies to promote social skills  based on adolescent participation.

3390/A0/04/015/002.status_value: Level 3: national Cuna Más programme has a strategy to improve staff capacity: 1. Design of an information-gathering workshop in communities and a strategy for the dissemination and use of the information gathered  2. Text of the guide for support workers and text of the 4 exercise cards for caregivers and facilitators 3. Design of a training session on the importance of positive childrearing practices
3390/A0/04/015/002.indicator_name: Number of institutions including strategies to improve parenting practices non-violent families.
3390/A0/04/015/002.headline: The national Cuna Más programme has a strategy for improving staff capacity to promote positive and non-violent child-rearing practices in its services. Evidence has been generated on the impact of corporal punishment on learning and development outcomes in schools.
3390/A0/04/015/002.baseline_value: 01 national institution designed a strategy to improve parenting practices non-violent families

3390/A0/04/001/001.indicator_name: Proportion of pregnant women with 6 or more prenatal care visits.
Proportion of newborns with 2 or more ante-natal care visits during the first month.
Coverage of HIV screening of pregnant women in the prioritized regions.
Coverage of screening for syphilis in pregnant women in prioritized regions.

3390/A0/04/015/001.status_value: a. Law 30403  which expressly prohibits corporal punishment in all settings  is adopted.  b. The Ministry of Women and Vulnerable Populations has draft legislation for protection of children without  or at risk of losing  parental care. The draft legislation includes a legal distinction between risk of neglect and neglect  differential measures and periodic review of the adopted measure.
3390/A0/04/015/001.indicator_name: There is a legal framework which prohibits physical punishment  improve the guarantees of access to justice and the protection of children without parental care.
3390/A0/04/015/001.headline: Peru adopted a law that prohibits corporal punishment in all settings  drafted a law for the protection of children without parental care  and generated publically available evidence on the prevalence and determinants of violence. Local governments invested more than US$ 4 million in projects related to child protection.
3390/A0/04/015/001.baseline_value: There is no legal prohibition of corporal punishment. There is no legal distinction between risk and abandonment. No legal obligation to review the extent of protection.

3390/A0/04/015/001.status_value: Level 2: The country report on the prevalence and contributing factors to violence against children was adopted by the multi-sectoral commission of the National Action Plan for Children and Adolescents
3390/A0/04/015/001.indicator_name: There is available information on prevalence  incidence and determinants of violence against children.
3390/A0/04/015/001.headline: Peru adopted a law that prohibits corporal punishment in all settings  drafted a law for the protection of children without parental care  and generated publically available evidence on the prevalence and determinants of violence. Local governments invested more than US$ 4 million in projects related to child protection.
3390/A0/04/015/001.baseline_value: There is no available information on prevalence  incidence and determinants of violence against children.

3390/A0/04/015/001.status_value: Decrease in national public spending on child protection from 1.57 % in 2014 to 0.89% in 2016.
3390/A0/04/015/001.indicator_name: % of increase in public budget for issues identified as priorities for protection at the national and regional level.
3390/A0/04/015/001.headline: Peru adopted a law that prohibits corporal punishment in all settings  drafted a law for the protection of children without parental care  and generated publically available evidence on the prevalence and determinants of violence. Local governments invested more than US$ 4 million in projects related to child protection.
3390/A0/04/015/001.baseline_value: 1.57% of national public budget allocated to child protection issues.

3390/A0/04/015/004.status_value: RENIEC has a National Plan 2016-2021 ¿Closing gaps in registration¿ that includes an assessment of disparities in registration based on the MORES methodology  guidelines  outcomes and indicators.
3390/A0/04/015/004.indicator_name: The RENIEC has a strategy to eliminate the under-registration of indigenous children.
3390/A0/04/015/004.headline: In Peru  97 per cent of children under the age of five have a birth certificate. There is a registration policy focused on improving the civil registration system and removing bottlenecks that limit free  timely and universal registration in indigenous communities.
3390/A0/04/015/004.baseline_value: There is not a strategy to eliminate the under-registration of indigenous children

3390/A0/04/015/005.status_value: There is an agreement with the Ministry of Women and Vulnerable Populations to revise content of the training programme  including response to emergencies  in 2016.
3390/A0/04/015/005.indicator_name: There is a training programme for operators of CEM and DEMUNAS.
3390/A0/04/015/005.headline: There is draft legislation for an alternative care system. The government has committed to deinstitutionalize children without parental care and develop family-based models of alternative care. Care pathways for victims of violence have been designed at the national regional levels.
3390/A0/04/015/005.baseline_value: There is not a training programme for operators of CEM and DEMUNAS.

3390/A0/04/015/005.status_value: 01 care pathway to protect children in street situations or at-risk children is adopted in the region of Ayacucho.  In progress: 2 regions have proposed care pathways that are pending adoption and development of a protocol.
3390/A0/04/015/005.indicator_name: Number of inter-agency protocols approved in selected regions.
3390/A0/04/015/005.headline: There is draft legislation for an alternative care system. The government has committed to deinstitutionalize children without parental care and develop family-based models of alternative care. Care pathways for victims of violence have been designed at the national regional levels.
3390/A0/04/015/005.baseline_value: There is no inter-agency protocols  established in selected regions  addressing child victims of violence and abandonment

3390/A0/04/015/005.status_value: In progress: there is information on children without parental care to inform the definition of indicators  The department of child protection investigations is validating the system of information on children served by child protection investigation units.
3390/A0/04/015/005.indicator_name: There is a system of information of children without parental care
3390/A0/04/015/005.headline: There is draft legislation for an alternative care system. The government has committed to deinstitutionalize children without parental care and develop family-based models of alternative care. Care pathways for victims of violence have been designed at the national regional levels.
3390/A0/04/015/005.baseline_value: There is not an information system of children without parental care covering minimum how many are institutionalized (CARs) and how many are in other types of foster care.

3390/A0/04/015/005.status_value: There is a high-level agreement with the Ministry of Women and Vulnerable Populations to develop a plan to deinstitutionalize children without parental care 2017 - 2021. By December 2016 there will be ministerial agreement on next steps for the deinstitutionalization of children.
